2.1 Open population model with 2 age classes
2.1.1 Model description
text:
Population dynamics represented using female-based age-structured open
population model pre-breeding census spring. census, females 
divided two age classes: “yearlings” (1-year old birds hatched 
breeding season previous year) “adults” (birds older one year).
motivation underlying distinction reproductive output often
differs two age classes passerine birds.
dynamics female segment population time-interval 
census year \(t\) census year \(t+1\) can described classic matrix
notation (Caswell 2001) :\[N_{tot,t+1} = \begin{bmatrix} N_{Y,t+1} \\ N_{,t+1} \end{bmatrix} =
  \begin{bmatrix}
0.5F_{Y,t}sJ_t & 0.5F_{,t}sJ_t \\
sA_t & sA_t
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} N_{Y,t} \\ N_{,t} \end{bmatrix} +
  \begin{bmatrix} Imm_{Y,t+1} \\ Imm_{,t+1} \end{bmatrix}\]\(N_{tot,t+1}\) represents total number yearling adult females 
population upon arrival breeding areas year t. total female
population size, \(N_{tot,t+1}\), sum numbers yearling adult
females population year \(t+1\) (\(N_{Y,t+1}\) \(N_{,t+1}\),
respectively) consists local survivors recruits previous
breeding season, well immigrant yearling (\(Imm_{Y,t+1}\)) adult
(\(Imm_{,t+1}\)) females.\(F_{,t}\) represents expected number fledglings produced age class \(\)
females breeding season year \(t\) product several
vital rates. First, females age class may breed nestbox 
probability \(pB_{,t}\) upon arrival breeding areas year \(t\). breeding
female may lay clutch containing certain number eggs (expected
number = \(CS_{,t}\)), egg within clutch may hatch survive 
fledging. probability egg hatching surviving fledging 
divided age-independent probability nest success (\(pNS_t\),
probability complete clutch failure = \(1-pNS_t\)) survival probability
every egg/chick fledging provided nest failed entirely
(\(sN_{,t}\), \(\) = age mother). Consequently, expected number 
fledglings produced age class \(\) females year t defined :\[\begin{equation}
F_{,t}= pB_{,t}\times CS_{,t}\times pNS_{t}\times sN_{,t}
\end{equation}\]Fledglings survive next breeding season remain within 
population (probability = \(sJ_t\)) contribute next year’s yearling class
(\(N_{Y,t+1}\)). Yearlings adults survive next breeding season 
remain within population (probability = \(sA_t\)) become part next year’s
adult age class (\(N_{,t+1}\)).

heading: 2.2 Data likelihoods
text:
IPMs obtain information population model’s parameters (population sizes
vital rates) several different data sets. Information data set
channeled model parameters via one multiple data likelihoods.
SPI-IPM contains five data modules consisting total eight data
likelihoods: nest count data (one likelihood), clutch size data (two likelihoods),
fledgling count data (three likelihoods), mark-recapture data (one likelihood),
immigrant count data (one likelihood).
likelihoods contained data module described detail 
following sub-chapters. underlying data sets introduced 
Chapter 1 manual.

heading: 2.2.1 Nest count data likelihood
text:
population model defines true size female segment breeding
population year \(t\) via year- age-specific number breeding
females:\[\begin{equation}
B_{,t}  \sim Binomial(N_{,t}, pB_{,t})
\end{equation}\]total size female breeding population (sum \(B_{,t}\) 
age classes) year \(t\) expected correspond closely observed
number first clutches laid year (\(NestCount_t\)).
breeding population count thus contains information breeding
probability (\(pB_{,t}\)) population size (\(N_{,t}\)) likelihood can
defined :\[\begin{equation}
NestCount_t  \sim Poisson((B_{Y,t} + B_{,t}) \times NS\_Data_t)
\end{equation}\], year-specific variable \(NS\_Data_t\) correction factor introduced
dealing years nest survey data collected
(\(NestCount_t = 0\) due lack sampling). \(NS\_Data_t\) set 0 years
without data collection, 1 years.likelihood written almost identically code, difference
use sum() function age classes \(1\) \(=2\)

extending model two age classes):

heading: 2.2.4 Mark-recapture data likelihood
text:
SPI-IPM, capture histories marked birds analysed using age-specific Cormack-Jolly-Seber (CJS) model (Cormack 1964; Jolly 1965; Seber 1965), allows estimation parameters associated annual survival (re-)capturing process.
survival parameters \(sJ_t\) \(sA_t\) describe probability surviving one breeding season next fledglings/juveniles adult females, respectively. Since field-based sexing fledglings possible hatch year, first-year survival CJS likelihood set \(0.5sJ_t\), representing probability fledgling female survives (recaptures adult males removed capture histories).
time- age-dependent recapture parameters \(p_{Age,t}^{Recap}\) describe probability age class \(\) individual recaptured identified breeding season year \(t\) given survived time interval \(t-1\) \(t\). many bird populations included SPI-Birds, (re-)captures birds carried nestboxes breeding season . Consequently, two conditions need met (re-)capture besides individual alive: 1) individual breeds nestbox (non-breeders birds breeding natural cavities captured) 2) individual actually captured marked/identified breeding nestbox. recapture probability therefore product probability breeding nestbox (\(pB_{Age,t}\)) probability capture identification given breeding nestbox (\(p_t^{CapB}\)):
\[\begin{equation}
  p_{Age,t}^{Recap}=pB_{Age,t}\times p_t^{CapB}
\end{equation}\]
parameters \(pB_{Age,t}\) \(p_t^{CapB}\) confounded, auxiliary data one required separately estimate . , raw data annual proportions surveyed nests identity breeding female recorded (result ringing recapture) used approximated \(p_t^{CapB}\), allowing CJS model estimate age- time-specific breeding probabilities (\(pB_{Age,t}\)).
CJS models Bayesian frameworks traditionally implemented either latent states models Bernouilli likelihoods multinomial likelihoods data re-formatted “m-arrays” (Gimenez et al. 2007; Kéry Schaub 2011). former typically results long runtimes high computational costs, improved efficiency latter tied implementation suffers neither particularly intuitive user-friendly. avoid pitfalls, CJS model SPI-IPM implemented using much efficient marginalized likelihood (integrates latent states) can applied unique (individual) capture histories (following Turek, de Valpine, Paciorek 2016):practice, involves use custom distribution dCJS_vv_sum, information likelihood implementation using NIMBLE provided Chapter 4.1 (Efficient implementation using NIMBLE).
code:
## Likelihood with custom distribution
for (i in 1:n.CH){

  y.sum[i, first.sum[i]:last.sum[i]] ~ dCJS_vv_sum(
      probSurvive = phi.CH[i, first.sum[i]:last.sum[i]],
      probCapture = p.CH[i, first.sum[i]:last.sum[i]],
      len = last.sum[i]-first.sum[i]+1,
      mult = CHs.count[i])
}

heading: 3 Modelling temporal variation
text:
Vital rates expected vary among years due changes environmental
conditions. SPI-IPM set account among-year variation 
different (age-specific) vital rates \(X_{,t}\) using fixed effects 
supplied environmental covariates (\(cov1_t\), \(cov2_t\),…) year random effects (\(\epsilon_t^X\)). resulting generalized linear
mixed-models time- age-specific vital rates therefore take following
form:
\[\begin{equation}
  link(X_{,t}) = link(\mu_a^X) + \beta_{cov1}^X\times cov1_t + \beta_{cov2}^X\times cov2_t + ... + \epsilon_t^X
\end{equation}\]
, \(\mu_a^X\) age-specific average vital rate (intercept) \(\beta_{cov1}\)
\(\beta_{cov2}\) slopes effects covariates \(cov1\) \(cov2\)
link scale, respectively.
link function depends vital rate, set logit breeding
probabilities (\(pB_{,t}\)), nest success probabilities (\(pNS_t\)), survival
probabilities (\(sN_{,t}\), \(sJ_t\), \(sA_t\)) log clutch size (\(CS_{,t}\)).

heading: 3.1 Random year variation

random year effects included basic implementation SPI-IPM 
assumed normally distributed 
\[\begin{equation}
  \epsilon_{t}^X \sim Normal(0, \sigma^X)
\end{equation}\]
\(\sigma^X\) standard deviation random year effects vital rate
\(X_{,t}\).
random effects basic implementation also age-independent, meaning
\(\epsilon_t^X\) included equations yearling vital
rate \(X_{Y,t}\) adults vital rate \(X_{,t}\). exception annual
survival rates juveniles (\(sJ_t\)) (\(sA_t\)), separate
random effects drivers survival variation expected vary
two age classes, basic implementation includes 
additional covariate effect \(sJ_t\) only2:random effects treated independent (= correlated) basic
implementation model, inclusion correlation random effects
across age-classes /vital rates straightforward implement3 using e.g.
multivariate normal distributions approaches similar one used 
Nater et al. (2020).
code:
for(t in 1:Tmax){
    
  ## Age- and time-dependent survival probabilities
  logit(sJ[t]) <- logit(Mu.sJ) + beta3.sJ*cov3[t] + epsilon.sJ[t]
  logit(sA[t]) <- logit(Mu.sA) + epsilon.sA[t]

  ## Temporal random effects
    epsilon.sJ[t] ~ dnorm(0, sd = sigma.sJ)
    epsilon.sA[t] ~ dnorm(0, sd = sigma.sA)
}

heading: 3.2.1 Continuous variables
text:
Continuous variables included covariate effects using specific slope
parameter (\(\beta\)). Temporal effects take form

quantifying strength direction effect \(cov1_t\) value

\(pNS_t\), example, codes as4:basic implementation SPI-IPM includes following covariate models:
\[\begin{align*}
  & logit(pNS_t) = logit(\mu^{pNS}) + \beta_{cov1}^{pNS}\times cov1_t + \beta_{cov2}^{pNS} \times cov2_t + \epsilon_t^{pNS} \\
  & logit(sN_{,t}) = logit(\mu_a^{pNS}) + \beta_{cov1}^{sN}\times cov1_t + \beta_{cov2}^{sN} \times cov2_t + \epsilon_t^{sN} \\
  & logit(sJ_t) = logit(\mu^{sJ}) + \beta_{cov3}^{sJ}\times cov3_t + \epsilon_t^{sJ}
\end{align*}\]

heading: 4.1 Efficient implementation using NIMBLE
text:
SPI-IPM implemented Bayesian framework , specifically, 
fit using NIMBLE (de Valpine et al. 2017). many ways, NIMBLE successor 
BUGS JAGS, using similar syntax offering higher efficiency, much
flexibility, range smaller “quality--life improvements”.
Unlike predecessors, NIMBLE software installed
via R-package nimble (de Valpine et al. 2021). lot resources setting

likelihood specified using distribution (dCJS_vv_sum) 
similar runtimes implementations using m-arrays small medium-sized
datasets, outspeed m-array formulations larger datasets.
specification custom distribution contained dCJS_CustomDist.R
implementation within model code looks quite minimalistic:y.sum matrix containing n.CH unique capture histories 
likelihood fit range observations first capture 
individual (first.sum) last possible time individual still
alive5(last.sum). probSurvive 
probCapture vectors containing survival recapture probabilities
relevant capture history (see IPMSetup.R Chapter 2.2.4 details). argument len quantifies length y.sum
required successful compilation custom function. Finally, mult
integer number specifying many individual birds shared capture history
.
code:
## Likelihood with custom distribution
for (i in 1:n.CH){
  y.sum[i, first.sum[i]:last.sum[i]] ~ dCJS_vv_sum(
       probSurvive = phi.CH[i, first.sum[i]:last.sum[i]],
       probCapture = p.CH[i, first.sum[i]:last.sum[i]],
       len = last.sum[i]-first.sum[i]+1,
       mult = CHs.count[i])
}
